summary: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos says truth-telling is a learned skill, not a natural instinct . Bezos implements meeting strategies such as speaking last and encouraging junior voices to go first . The goal is to make sure that anyone can question assumptions without fear of repercussion .  Bezos: "Truths are often... uncomfortable. They can be awkward, they can be exhausting" Bezos also advocated for listening to instinct when hard data is unavailable . Leaders must rely on both intuition and evidence and be wary of optimism bias .  Bezos' instincts have led to immense success: Amazon shares have climbed 56.62% over the past five years . Bezos now has a net worth of $209 billion, making him the world's third-richest person behind Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg .  Separates Great Companies From The Rest . The S&P 500 (^GSPC) soared nearly 3.3% to its highest level since March 3 . The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) gained 2.8%, or more than 1,100 points . The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) led gains, rocketing up 4.3%.  The S&P 500 (^GSPC) soared 3.3%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) gained 2.3% on Monday . April’sConsumer Price Index (CPI) report is due Tuesday, followed by retail sales and the Producer Price Index on Thursday .  Bitcoin (BTC-USD) fell more than 2% on Monday to hover below $102,000 per token . The world's largest cryptocurrency touched a session high north of $105,000 before declining . Bitcoin is up more than 8% year-to-date .  Comments of tariffs in the industrials sector climbed to 61 from 10 during the post-election period . Some companies have pulled their outlook during this past earnings season, citing uncertainty stemming from tariffs . President Trump excluded auto imports from the tariff pause his administration reached with China on Monday .  West Texas Intermediate (CL=F) futures rallied over 2% to hover near $62.50 per barrel . Brent crude (BZ=F), the international benchmark, also rebounded to trade above $65 . Monday's oil price rally was exacerbated by a likely short position covering after talks between the US and China resulted in a 90-day pause on tariffs .  President Trump promised to cut the cost of pharmaceutical drugs in the US on Monday via an executive order . "We're getting them down 67%, 80%, 90%," Trump said . The president said the US has the highest prices in the world, as pharmaceutical companies make most of their profits .  Gold futures tumbled 3% as investors jumped into equities, selling off the safe-haven asset . Trump said he plans to speak with China's President Xi Jinping, "maybe at the end of the week" The precious metal is up roughly 24% year to date after a massive run-up .  Big Tech stocks continue to rally premarket on temporary reprieve in US and China tariffs . Amazon (AMZN) and Tesla (TSLA) lead the morning's "Magnificent Seven" gains . The Nasdaq Composite (IXIC) surged over 3%, while the S&P 500 (GSPC) soared 3%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) jumped more than 2.4%, or over 1,000 points .  US tech stocks rallied across the board on news of a US-China trade deescalation . Amazon (AMZN) spiked 7.6% on Monday morning . Apple (AAPL) surged 6.2%, Meta (META) added 5.5%, and Alphabet (GOOG,GOOGL) advanced 2.4% .  S&P 500 futures climbed 3%, while Dow Jones Industrial Average futures gained 2.4%, or around 1,000 points . Nasdaq 100 (NQ=F) led gains, soaring 3.8% . Meanwhile, the US dollar (DX-Y.NYB) gained 1.4% and Bitcoin (BTC-USD) declined slightly, down 0.25% . Gold (GC) tumbled 3.6% to trade around $3,220 per ounce .  Crude oil, copper (HG=F) and crop futures rose, but gold prices sank after the US and China said they had agreed to a mutual reduction in tariffs . Brent crude rose 2.4% to trade above $65 a barrel, WTI crude jumped 2.6% to almost $63 a barrel .  Both sides described recent US-China trade negotiations as showing “substantial progress” Bloomberg reports: Read more here. looked for concrete outcomes from recent U.S.-China trade talks .

Amazon says its Prime Video streaming service with ads reaches more than 130 million U.S. customers monthly on average . The company said it believes it is "uniquely positioned to connect content to customers" Amazon will make a presentation later on Monday in New York as part of the TV industry's annual "upfronts"  Prime Video will continue to stream the Academy of Country Music Awards for the next three years . Prime Video also has shows like fashion reality show "Making the Cut," where customers can buy clothing seen on the show on Amazon .  Investors have put more pressure on streamers to increase profits, causing them to look for other ways to make money . In 2022,Netflixintroduced an ad-supported subscription plan .

UPS (NYSE:UPS) reported revenue ahead of Wall Street’s expectations in Q1 CY2025, but sales were flat year on year at $21.55 billion . Its non-GAAP profit of $1.49 per share was 8.2% above analysts’ consensus estimates . Is now the time to buy UPS?  Consolidated operating margin improved 20 basis points to 8.2%, driven by a 110 basis point expansion in U.S. Domestic margin to 7.0% . CEO Carol Tome highlighted the accelerated reduction of specific Amazon volumes and new cost-reduction initiatives as key to offsetting softer demand, especially among small and midsize business customers .  UPS is undertaking its largest network reconfiguration ever, aiming to complete 164 operational closures . B2B (up 1.5%) and healthcare saw positive volume trends, while B2C (down 7%) and Ground Saver (down 8.4%) volumes declined .  China-to-U.S. trade lane is highly profitable (11% of International revenue) Potential shifts in supply chain sourcing could impact both volume and revenue distribution in future periods . Management’s outlook for the coming quarters is defined by its continued cost-cutting actions, evolving trade policies, and efforts to shift toward higher-margin business segments .  The outcome of pending U.S.-China tariffs and changes to customs thresholds remain major unknowns . SMB customers, often single-sourced from China, will be disproportionately pressured by these changes . UPS prioritizing healthcare logistics and expansion in international markets .  Management cited increased uncertainty for SMBs from tariffs and "chaos costs" related to building closures as near-term margin pressures . Management detailed plans for 400 automated facilities and emphasized the role of automation in reducing labor dependency .  Management explained that while inventory reductions could weigh on near-term volumes, shifts in trade lanes and sourcing may mitigate long-term effects . Key catalysts include the pace and execution of UPS’s network reconfiguration, including 164 operational closures by end of June .  The outlook for 2025 is clouded by new trade policies that could impact business confidence and growth . Take advantage of Mr. Market by checking out ourTop 6 Stocks for this week . Both sides agreed to pause some tariffs for 90 days, signaling a potential turning point in ongoing tensions . This rollback cuts U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods to 30% and 10% . President Trump clarified that tariffs could go "substantially higher" if a full deal with China wasn't reached during the 90-day pause .  The shares closed the day at $208.74, up 8.1% from previous close . Amazon’s shares are extremely volatile and have had 41 moves greater than 2.5% over the last year . Lower tariffs reduce cost pressures and restore cross-border demand .  Amazon is down 5.3% since the beginning of the year, and at $208.61 per share, it is trading 13.8% below its 52-week high of $242.06 from February 2025 . Investors who bought $1,000 worth of Amazon’s shares 5 years ago would now be looking at an investment worth .

On Monday, President Trump announced a 90-day pause that will reduce US tariffs on Chinese goods to 30% from 145% . China, in turn, will lower its tariffs on US goods from 125% to 10% . CFRA analyst Arun Sundaram calls the move a "positive development for retailers"  On Monday, top retail stock gainers include Amazon (AMZN), Target (TGT), Best Buy (BBY), Dollar Tree (DLTR), Five Below (FIVE), Wayfair (W), and Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) The big unknown is what happens after August 10 . Another tariff change can compound issues on top of higher shipping costs and supply chain complications .  Walmart (WMT) and Costco (COST) remain top picks for Wall Street . With the reduction of tariff risk, things could be looking up for Best Buy, Feldman said . Walmart shares are up nearly 60% in the past year, and Costco shares up nearly 28% .  Jefferies analyst Corey Tarlowe says Walmart has the ability and scale to do at the size that Walmart can . Feldman also likes Lowe's and Home Depot, which could benefit from a "relief rally" should discretionary spending recover . Bank of America sees significant cost-saving potential in Amazon’s growing use of robotics and autonomous vehicles . Amazon said robots already assist with roughly 75% of customer orders, but BofA expects that “robot touchpoints per package” will grow .  Robotics are already being scaled up at Amazon’s 12th Generation Fulfillment Center in Shreveport, Louisiana . The bank believes these systems could reduce labor costs, cut injury-related expenses, and improve order accuracy, helping to minimize returns, which MWPVL estimates make up about 20% of fulfillment and delivery costs .  Index sees biggest turnover since 2022 as trade tensions reshape index . Index has highest turnover since 2012 as it seeks to keep up pace with rising share prices . Index was up 0.6% on Tuesday, down 0.2% on Wednesday .

US-China tariff standstill may mean the "Magnificent Seven" trade does anything but stay in place . The US and China agreed on Monday to reduce "reciprocal" tariffs on goods from China to 10% from 125% . The Roundhill Magnificent Seven ETF (MAGS) ripped 6% in premarket trading .  Traders use the Roundhill Magnificent Seven ETF as a proxy for the Mag 7, as its top holdings are the seven stocks . China will cut its retaliatory tariffs on US goods to 10% from 125% . The Mag 7 trade was climbing back into top form after a challenging stretch this year .  Goldman Sachs data shows Mag 7 companies delivered 28% average earnings growth in the first quarter . The 493 other stocks in the S&P 500 delivered only 9% growth . Some pros continue to advise caution before going all in again on the Mag 7 . Zacks.com releases the list of companies likely to issue earnings surprises . This week’s list includes Walmart WMT, Target TGT and Amazon AMZN . Walmart shares were down following the last quarterly release on February 20th .  Management touched on some of these trends in its April 9th investor day event, noting some near-term tariff-related challenges . Walmart has been coming ahead of its target over the last two years, with sales up +5.5% . Management noted that roughly two-thirds of U.S. sales are from domestically-sourced products .  Walmart’s value orientation and well-executed digital strategy have been key to gaining grocery market share by attracting higher-income households . E-commerce accounts for an estimated 15% of total ex-gasoline sales at present, which management sees eventually increasing to more than double that level over time . Walmart is expected to report $0.58 in EPS on $165.6 billion in revenues .  Target's estimate aligns with management’s original guidance of 57 to 58 cents per share . Same-store sales (ex-fuel) are expected to be up +3.21% for the quarter, compared to +4.9% in the preceding period . Target's general merchandise business got off to a weak start, but trends improving later in the quarter .  Total Q1 earnings for these 20 retailers that have reported are up +20.2% from the same period last year on +6.9% higher revenues . The Zacks Retail sector includes Walmart, Target, and other traditional retailers, online vendors like Amazon, and restaurant players .  Over 500 companies on deck to report results this week, including 11 S&P 500 members . Earnings for the group outside of Amazon are down -6.3% on a +5.4% top-line gain .  Total earnings for these 452 index members are up +12.2% from the same period last year on +4.4% revenue gains . 73.7% of the companies beating EPS estimates and 61.9% beating revenue estimates . Q1 as a whole, combining the actuals from the 452 S&P 500 members with estimates for the still-to-come companies .  The magnitude of cuts to 2025 Q2 estimates since the start of the period is bigger and more widespread relative to what we have become used to seeing in the post-COVID period . But we are starting to notice a curious development with the Tech sector estimate, both for Q2 as well as full-year 2025 .  Estimates for full-year 2025 have also come under pressure in recent weeks, with the negative revisions trend becoming very meaningful and widespread since mid-February 2025 . That said, if the trend continues for a few more weeks, it will be hard to interpret this development as a clear sign that the earnings picture has clearly stabilized and started to strengthen . The FTSE 100 (^FTSE) and European indices climbed on Monday . London's premier index was 0.6% higher by the closing bell . US stocks surged at the opening bell as details of a temporary trade deal with China came into focus .  The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) surged 2.3%, or around 1,000 points . The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) led gains, rocketing up 3.5% . Investors jumped into shares of Big Tech megacaps bruised by trade war worries .  UK companies are increasingly targeting high-potential markets outside the EU . Ireland and Italy have fallen out of the top ten export destinations for the first time since 2022 . India is also back in focus following the signing of a new UK-India trade agreement .  Gold futures were down by 3.5% to $3,226.30 per ounce, while the spot gold price lost 2.8% . The drop follows constructive trade discussions over the weekend that market participants interpreted as a potential turning point in strained relations between the world’s two largest economies .  Gold dips amid risk-on mood sparked by the US-China trade agreement that dulls demand for safe havens . The substantial rollback in duties, coupled with growing optimism about further trade deals with other partners, opens the door for a deeper pullback in gold prices . However, relief may prove short-lived as trade uncertainty is likely to persist .  The drop in Novo Nordisk (NOVO-B.CO) shares, as well as other pharmaceuticals stocks, came after president Trump vowed to cut US drug prices . Trump said that he would be signing "one of the most consequential Executive Orders" in US history on Monday .  A handful of miners and investment firms are topping London's premier index, which is up 0.5% as of 10.15am . Shares in FTSE-listed drugmakers AstraZeneca and GSK were down 4% and 2.4% respectively . Swiss company Roche (ROG.SW) fell nearly 3% and French company Sanofi dipped 1.6% .  The US dollar index (DX-Y.NYB) was up 1% to $101.32 . The gains were driven by a weekend announcement from the United States that it had reached a preliminary trade deal with China . Both sides said on Monday they would suspend 24% of additional ad valorem tariffs on goods from the other country for 90 days .  Expectations of tighter monetary conditions ahead pushed the greenback to a one-month high . The rate that UK businesses are laying people off gained pace in April . Employer confidence levels at an all-time low following the legislated increase in National Insurance payments and rise in the national living wage .  Dow Jones Industrial Average (YM=F) futures rose by over 480 points, or 1.2%, on Monday . Nasdaq 100 futures led gains with a 2.2% jump . The market-friendly momentum followed a weekend of high-level trade talks in Switzerland . The rally comes after a downbeat week for stocks .  Market watchers will have one eye on developments in president Donald Trump's trade negotiations as well as movements towards peace in the Russia-Ukraine war .

Ecommerce penetration as a percentage of overall retail would grow 1-2% annually, but in 2020 adoption accelerated by 5%, reaching 25% . Consumers ever rising demand for convenience, selection, and speed are secular engines underpinning ecommerce adoption .  Wayfair reported revenues of $2.73 billion, flat year on year . This print exceeded analysts’ expectations by 0.7% . Despite the top-line beat, it was still a mixed quarter for the company .  Carvana reported revenues of $4.23 billion, up 38.3% year on year, outperforming analysts’ expectations by 6.2% . Carvana scored the biggest analyst estimates beat and fastest revenue growth among its peers . Wayfair delivered the slowest revenue growth of the whole group .  Amazon reported revenues of $155.7 billion, up 8.6% year on year, in line with analysts’ expectations . Revolve (NASDAQ:RVLV) is a fashion retailer leveraging social media and a community of fashion influencers to leverage social media . The market seems content with the results as the stock is up 3.9% since reporting .  Revolve reported revenues of $296.7 million, up 9.7% year on year . Coupang (NYSE:CPNG) is an e-commerce giant often referred to as the "Amazon of South Korea" The stock is down 6.6% since reporting and currently trades at $17.70 .  Inflation cooled significantly from its post-pandemic highs, drawing closer to the 2% goal . This disinflation has occurred without severely impacting economic growth . Kevin O'Leary, the entrepreneur and investor known as Mr. Wonderful from “Shark Tank,” recently shared his thoughts on loyalty programs . “Loyalty programs? Don't fall for the hype. Points are inflating faster than the dollar," he wrote on Xrecently .  O'Leary's strategy is to cash out as soon as possible, taking advantage of any opportunity to spend them before their value drops further . He suggests using them for goods and services wherever possible, like on Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN), to avoid being caught in the cycle of point inflation .  O'Leary's approach is simple: collect points but never hold onto them for long . Even if you manage to earn a million points in a year, that's only about $10,000 in value . "The game is rigged" against those who try to save up for larger rewards, he says .  You can invest today for just $0.30/share with a $1000 minimum . Don't repeat history—invest in RYSE at just $1.90/share .  'The Game Is Rigged' Says Kevin O'Leary on Credit Card Points . He Claims They're Inflating Faster Than The Dollar And Always Cashes Out Fast .

Major benchmarks are down this year amid concerns about import tariffs and their impact on economic growth . These uncertain times actually offer investors a great opportunity -- and with $1,000 or much less, you can seize it .  Long-term investors can buy quality, well-established companies for reasonable, and sometimes dirt cheap, prices . With this amount or even less, you can get in on all the following, or decide to bet on just one .  Nvidia has generated record levels of revenue -- and at levels of high profitability with gross margin wider than 70% . Nvidia has $43 billion in cash to support its fast-paced development . Target used the early pandemic period to maximize convenience for shoppers, growing its digital sales .  Target shares have slumped 57% over the past three years . Amazon's e-commerce and cloud computing businesses are starting to greatly benefit from decisions the company made a few years ago . The company revamped its cost structure and shifted to a regional fulfillment model .  Amazon Web Services has invested heavily in AI, which has brought the unit to a $117 billion annual revenue run rate . The e-commerce and cloud businesses have kept growth going steadily at Amazon in recent times . In the latest quarter, net sales, rising 9%, topped $155 billion .  Nvidia is 31x forward earnings estimates now, making it a fantastic place to park your $1,000 . Apple, Netflix and Nvidia are among the companies that are about to pop . Now is the best time to buy before it’s too late .  Market, an Amazon subsidiary, is a member of The Motley Fool's board of directors . Adria Ciminohas positions in Amazon and Target .
